newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - October 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - October 23.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for Reuters by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi. Telephone: 11-3324842, 11-3761233; Fax: 91-11-3351006 Internet : biznis.news@forums.sprintrpg.sprint.com
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
TOP STORIES
Hindustan Times
VAGHELA SET TO FORM GOVERNMENT IN GUJARAT

The Indian cabinet recommended revocation of president's rule in Gujarat state to help a popular government take charge following the governor's report that a stable administration could be formed. President's rule was imposed on September 19 after then chief minister Suresh Mehta claimed a majority amid violent scenes in the state assembly. Expelled Bharatiya Janata Party leader Sankarsinh Vaghela is likely to take over as the next chief minister. He claims to enjoy the support of 101 legislators in the 181-member assembly, including 45 Congress and 13 Independent members.
The Economic Times
STOCK MARKETS RALLY, BSE GAINS 97 POINTS

Indian stock markets turned buoyant on fresh buying support after the boost offered by the new credit policy. The 30-share Bombay Stock Market sensitive index rose 3,235 points, up 96.92 points. Domestic buyers were seen building up fresh positions as foreign institutional investors took to aggressive buying in select scrips. Prices of Indian global depository receipts in London rose, with several issues up by five to 10 percent.
UNLISTED COMPANIES TURN TO FOREIGN INVESTORS FOR HELP

Faced with a cash crunch and high interest rates, unlisted companies are turning to foreign investors for help. These companies are looking to foreign investment bankers and fund managers to invest in debt instruments that they are keen to float. This follows a government decision to allow foreign institutional investors to invest in private domestic debt. Many of them are tapping the foreign currency markets. The government has already cleared 205 applications seeking external commercial borrowings up to $15 million.
Financial Express
TELECOM MAJOR ALLOWED TO CLUB GDR ISSUE WITH DIVESTMENT

The Minister of State for Communications, B.V. Verma has finally agreed to allow Videsh Sanchar Nigam Ltd (VSNL) to club its global depository receipt (GDR) offering with the government's divestment plans. VSNL had asked for combining its GDR issue with the divestment programme to secure funds for the company's expansion. VSNL has drawn up an ambitious $1 billion investment programme spread over the next four years.
ICICI'S NET PROFIT RISES MARGINALLY

The Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India (ICICI) recorded a net profit of 2.66 billion rupees from an income of 17 billion rupees for the first half of fiscal 1996/97 (April-March). Compared with the previous corresponding period, net profit grew by only 15 million rupees. ICICI plans to raise $300 million from global markets and 15 billion rupees from the domestic market. Of this, five billion rupees will be through private placements, sources said. ICICI's capital adequacy ratio on September 30, 1996, stood at 12.4 percent. In the first half of 1996/97, ICICI's disbursements totalled 45.4 billion rupees against 32.6 billion rupees for the same period last year.
ANDHRA POWER UNIT TO GET 19.82 BLN YEN FUND FROM OECF

The Japan-based Overseas Economic Cooperation Fund has agreed to offer 19.82 billion yen as financial assistance for the proposed 1000-mw coal-based power station at Simhadri, Andhra Pradesh. The project is promoted by the National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC). The public sector major plans to set up two more power stations in Andhra Pradesh -- the 650-mw naphtha-based Hyderabad project and the 500-mw coal fired Ramagundam-III project. NTPC recorded a turnover of 83.87 billion rupees in fiscal 1995/96, ended last March.
PRIVATISATION OF COAL INDUSTRY DEMANDED

The power ministry and the central electricity authority (CEA) have asked for privatisation of the coal industry. The CEA has written to the government saying Coal India Ltd (CIL) and its subsidiaries had failed to fulfil their objective. The power ministry backed the move as a majority of the 63 power stations were complaining that CIL had failed to maintain the linkages for power generation resulting in break downs.
Business Standard
RELIANCE-DE BEERS AMONG FOUR MINING VENTURES CLEARED

The Foreign Investment Promotion Board has cleared four joint venture (JV) mining proposals. These include a 50-50 JV between Reliance and De Beers Consolidated for diamond prospecting in Madhya Pradesh. The others are BHP Minerals proposal for a wholly-owned holding company, a 50-50 JV between ACC and Australia's CRA and a 50-50 JV between multinational Hepworth and Mineral Development Corporation of Uttar Pradesh. The Reliance-De Beers JV involves setting up of a $30 million diamond mining project. The ACC-CRA venture proposes to explore bauxite, copper, diamond, gold and silver.
PUBLIC SECTOR BANKS SHY AWAY FROM SECONDARY MARKET

Most public sector banks are staying away from the secondary market. The recently announced busy season credit policy allowed banks to invest up to five percent of their incremental deposits in the secondary market. The central bank was keen on banks buying shares in the secondary markets so that the dependence of the market sentiments on foreign institutional investors was reduced. However, banks cold-houldered the secondary market due to a ck of fund managers and other problems.
PENALTY LIKELY FOR EXPORT CREDIT SHORTFALL

Most banks fear the central bank (RBI) might impose a penal interest rate in case they fail to meet the newly set 12 percent export credit target. It was stated in the recently announced credit policy that failure to achieve the stipulated level of export credit target could invite bank specific policy responses. The heads of public and private sector banks said the penalty could be in the form of doing away with export refinance facilities for the bank or restraining the refinance.
Business Line
CROP INSURANCE COVER FOR ALL FARMERS

Agriculture Minister Chaturanan Mishra has hinted at measures to step up agricultural production. These include a comprehensive crop insurance scheme, steps to decrease the rate of interest on agricultural loans and measures to boost production through improved technology. The minister said the new crop insurance scheme would be extended to all farmers. Currently, insurance cover was being provided only to farmers who had taken corp loans.
20 BLN RUPEE CAPITAL FOR UTI HOLDING COMPANY MOOTED

Unit Trust of India (UTI) has earmarked an authorised capital of 20 billion rupees for setting up a holding company. The proposal has been submitted to the finance ministry. According to sources, the proposed holding company will float an asset management company which will manage all the mutual fund schemes of UTI. The holding company will also control the other subsidiaries of UTI including UTI Investor Services Ltd, UTI bank, UTI securities and UTI Advisory Services Ltd.
The Observer
CAPITAL GOODS OUTPUT DIPS

Contrary to the impression that there was a slowdown in industrial growth, the sector wise performance in the first five months of the current fiscal showed mixed trends. An analysis by the Confederation of Indian Industries showed basic goods had performed better while capital goods suffered losses. intermediate and consumer goods generally maintained growth. In the capital goods sector, machine tools grew 30 percent, the same as in the previous year, as did diamond tools, at 20 percent.
PUBLIC SECTOR SELL OFF MAY FETCH ABOUT 20 BLN RUPEES

The government's second tranche of divestment of public sector unit (PSUs) shares, scheduled for this year end, may not fetch more than 20 billion rupees. The government hoped to raise about 50 billion rupees from PSU disinvestments. According to an assessment by a central bank economic analyst, ill-timing of disinvestment, poor capital market conditions and a poorer image of PSUs would be the factors responsible for a poor response to the disinvestment drive.
